Yes, over-fertilizing can be a significant problem in modern agriculture. When farmers apply too much fertilizer or apply it improperly, nutrients can leach out of the soil and contaminate nearby waterways, leading to environmental problems such as eutrophication and algal blooms. Over-fertilization can also cause soil degradation, decreased crop quality, and reduced yields.

Another consequence of over-fertilizing is the risk of plant toxicity. Some nutrients, such as nitrogen and potassium, can be toxic to plants in high concentrations, and overuse of fertilizers containing these nutrients can damage or kill the plants. In addition, over-fertilizing can disrupt the soil microbiome and adversely affect soil health, which can lead to long-term problems in the sustainability of the farming system.

To avoid these problems, farmers must carefully manage their fertilizer use and avoid over-application. This involves using precision application technologies, such as variable-rate application, and monitoring soil nutrient levels throughout the growing season to make informed fertilizer management decisions. By managing fertilizer use in this way, farmers can ensure nutrient balance while minimizing environmental impacts and maintaining the long-term health of their farming system.
